toxins.name: Clove Essential Oil (Categorized under essential oils known to be toxic to cats)
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ Hepatic Enzyme Deficiency: Cats possess a unique metabolic profile that lacks specific liver enzymes (specifically hepatic glucuronosyltransferase) required to break down and glucuronidate certain organic compounds found in essential oils2.
    ◦ Accumulation and Organ Damage: Because the cat's liver cannot effectively process or eliminate these toxins, they accumulate in the body, leading to serious organ damage, specifically liver failure34.
    ◦ Direct Irritation: The oil can cause chemical burns on the skin or in the mouth if ingested or applied topically3.
4. Notes on
toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ High Toxicity: The oil is considered toxic and can be harmful even in small quantities, such as a single drop of concentrated product4.
    ◦ "Neat" Application: The risk is highest when the oil is used "neat" (undiluted) rather than in low-concentration cosmetic products5. Toxicity can occur through ingestion (licking fur), inhalation, or direct skin contact

symptoms.name: Liver failure (Serious organ damage)
symptoms.onset: Not explicitly specified, though damage can occur rapidly or develop over time.
symptoms.notes: Essential oils can cause serious organ damage in cats; in extreme cases, this leads to liver failure because cats lack the specific liver enzymes needed to break down these compounds.Neurological Disturbances (Tremors and Ataxia)

symptoms.name: Tremors, shaking, and ataxia (walking as if drunk)
symptoms.notes: Cats may also experience collapse or seizures, indicating severe central nervous system toxicity.Respiratory Distress

symptoms.name: Difficulty breathing (Dyspnea) or breathing with the mouth open
symptoms.notes: This can occur from inhalation (diffusers) or aspiration if the cat vomits. Nebulized or ultrasonically diffused neat oils pose a greater risk.Chemical Burns

symptoms.name: Soreness, redness, or chemical burns
symptoms.notes: Direct skin contact with the oil can cause burns. Even if there is no visible damage to the skin, the cat may still be poisoned by absorbing the toxins or licking them off their fur.Gastrointestinal Upset

symptoms.name: Vomiting and excessive dribbling (hypersalivation)
symptoms.notes: Vomiting is a common sign of essential oil poisoning. High fat levels in carrier oils can also contribute to tummy upsets.Lethargy

symptoms.name: Lethargy, depression, or dullness
symptoms.notes: A general sign of systemic toxicity that often accompanies more specific symptoms.

treatments.name: Warm Water Bath with Liquid Dish Soap
treatments.description: If the cat has Clove oil on its skin or fur, the veterinarian (or owner, under guidance) must bathe the cat using lukewarm water and a liquid dish soap (degreaser) to thoroughly remove the oily residue. This prevents the cat from absorbing more toxins through the skin or ingesting them while grooming.
treatments.notes: This is urgent because cats are fastidious groomers. Do not use solvents or other cleaning products to remove the oil, as these can be toxic themselves.Oral Decontamination — Do NOT Induce Vomiting

treatments.name: Mouth Rinsing / Dilution
treatments.description: If the oil was ingested, the veterinarian may rinse the cat’s mouth with lukewarm water to remove localized traces of the oil. They may also administer small amounts of liquid (like milk or water) to dilute the substance.
treatments.notes: Inducing vomiting is contraindicated (not recommended) for essential oil ingestion. Clove oil can cause chemical burns to the mouth and esophagus; bringing it back up can worsen this damage or lead to aspiration (inhaling the oil into the lungs), which causes severe pneumonia.Aggressive Supportive Care (Fluids and Respiratory Support)

treatments.name: Intravenous (IV) Fluid Therapy and Oxygen Supplementation
treatments.description: The administration of IV fluids to maintain hydration, blood pressure, and assist the body in eliminating toxins. If the cat is experiencing difficulty breathing (a symptom of essential oil poisoning), oxygen therapy may be required.
treatments.notes: Essential oils can cause liver injury, seizures, and respiratory distress. Aggressive care is often needed to support the cat's organs while the liver attempts to process the toxins, a task made difficult by the cat's lack of specific liver enzymes (glucuronosyltransferase).Symptomatic Management (Pain and Seizure Control)

treatments.name: Analgesics and Anticonvulsants
treatments.description: Medications may be given to control tremors or seizures (neurological signs of toxicity) and to manage pain from chemical burns in the mouth or throat.
treatments.notes: Cats exposed to essential oils may show signs of CNS depression (dullness, wobbliness) or excitation (tremors). Liver protectants may also be administered if blood tests indicate hepatic damage.
